reasonsForBeingOther.label: No proofs
reasonsForBeingOther.shortDescription: The proof system isn't fully functional
reasonsForBeingOther.description: Projects without a proper proof system fully rely on single entities to safely update the state. A malicious proposer can finalize an invalid state, which can cause loss of funds.

display.name: Fuel Ignition
display.description: Fuel Ignition is a high-performance Ethereum L2 built on FuelVM and the Sway language.

stateValidation.description: Currently the system permits invalid state roots. More details in project overview.

dataAvailability.description: All of the data needed for proof construction is published on Ethereum L1.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1.

proposerFailure.description: Only the whitelisted proposers can publish state roots on L1, so in the event of failure the withdrawals are frozen.

requirements.description: The project calls itself a rollup.
State roots are posted to Ethereum L1.
Inputs for the state transition function are posted to Ethereum L1.

A source-available node exists that can recreate the state from Ethereum L1 data. Please note that the L2BEAT team has not verified the validity of the node source code. [View code](https://github.com/FuelLabs/network-watchtower)
The proof system is still under development.
Users' withdrawals can be censored by the permissioned operators.
Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.
The Security Council is not properly set up.
Upgrades unrelated to onchain provable bugs provide less than 30d to exit.
The Security Council's actions are not confined to onchain provable bugs.

stateCorrectness.name: Fraud proofs are in development
stateCorrectness.description: Ultimately, Fuel will use one round fraud proofs with single round performed via a RISC-V-based zkVM. Currently, there is a 7d challenge period.

risks.text: an invalid state root is submitted to the system by the proposer.

references.text: FuelChainState.sol - Etherscan source code, commit function

dataAvailability.name: All transaction data is recorded on chain
dataAvailability.description: All executed transactions are submitted to an on chain smart contract. The execution of the rollup is based entirely on the submitted transactions, so anyone monitoring the contract can know the correct state of the rollup chain.

operator.name: The system has a centralized sequencer
operator.description: While forcing transaction is open to anyone the system employs a privileged sequencer that has priority for submitting transaction batches and ordering transactions.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly.

references.text: FuelMessagePortalV3.sol - Etherscan source code, sendMessage function

exitMechanisms.name: Regular exit
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates the withdrawal by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is finalized the funds become available for withdrawal on L1. The process of block finalization usually takes several days to complete. Finally the user submits an L1 transaction to claim the funds. This transaction requires a merkle proof.

exitMechanisms.name: Forced exit
exitMechanisms.description: If the user experiences censorship from the operator with regular exit they can submit their withdrawal requests directly on L1. The system is then obliged to service this request or halt all withdrawals, including forced withdrawals from L1 and regular withdrawals initiated on L2. Once the force operation is submitted and if the request is serviced, the operation follows the flow of a regular exit.

otherConsiderations.name: Fuel operates via the FuelVM and the Sway language
otherConsiderations.description: The FuelVM makes use of the UTXO model and a register-based design to enable parallel transaction processing. The language used is Sway and it does not support Solidity contracts.

permissions.name: FuelChainState pausers
permissions.description: Whitelisted addresses that can pause the FuelChainState.

permissions.name: Sequencer
permissions.description: Permissioned address submitting tx data as blobs.

permissions.name: FuelMultisig
permissions.description: A Gnosis Safe with 10 / 13 threshold.  Can upgrade the FuelERC20Gateway, FuelMessagePortal and FuelChainState contracts, potentially gaining access to all funds. It can unpause contracts and remove L2->L1 messages from the blacklist. It can also limit the tokens that can be bridged to L2.

addresses.name: FuelERC20Gateway
addresses.description: Standard gateway to deposit and withdraw ERC20 tokens. It implements rate limits and a whitelist for tokens. The whitelist is currently active.

addresses.name: FuelMessagePortal
addresses.description: Contract that allows to send and receive arbitrary messages to and from L2. It implements a max deposit limit for ETH, currently set to 115792089237316195423570985008687907853269984665640564039457.584007913129639935 ETH, and rate limits withdrawals. Pausers are allowed to blacklist L2->L1 messages.
